issues.title: Remove things that were moved into draft-lenders-core-coap-dtls-svcb
issues.author: chrysn
issues.body:
Parts of this document are moved out as requested in the IETF119 CoRE meeting.

Once https://github.com/anr-bmbf-pivot/draft-lenders-core-coap-dtls-svcb is stripped down to what should be in there, those parts should be removed from this document.

pulls.title: Explain EDHOC or alternatives as OSCORE boostraps, add citations
pulls.author: chrysn

comments.body:
Can you add a date here as well, please, so the citation is complete. Currently it says `n.d.` in the rendered HTML

![image](https://github.com/anr-bmbf-pivot/draft-lenders-core-dnr/assets/675644/5166af4b-a526-4132-9a49-834f51d912b8)

```suggestion
    date: 2018-10
    target: https://omaspecworks.org/white-paper-lightweight-m2m-1-1/
```

pulls.title: Changes set from looking over the current alpha
pulls.author: chrysn

comments.body:
```suggestion
* There is ongoing work in addressing the trouble created by CoAP using a diverse set of URI schemas
```

Isn't it?
Should we also add “constrained networks” to the Terminology section?

```suggestion
thus, no values for it would be allocated for transports that use transport security.
```

and

```suggestion
thus, no values for it would be are allocated for transfer protocols that use transport security.
```
schemas would be the plural of schema; https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_URI_schemes (the URI literal) says that "schemes" is correct here.
It was used in the introduction before, but yes, added it.

pulls.title: IANA actions to establish "co" ALPN
pulls.author: chrysn
pulls.body:
This picks up https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/tls-reg-review/meMm8LYSxvn4BGIkikScM3BblOw/ -- once that is out in a draft, we'll get the ALPN.

We don't need to worry about document normativity here, the registry is expert review only -- they just want *some* place that has text.

And spare us a round trip: Yes, this is a problem statement document. If you insist on problem-statement-ish text, that may be

> The problem is trival for the DTLS case, as illustrated in section IANA considerations – those lines and a mail to the list was all it took to just register it. For the non-transport layer security layers, we're writing all the rest of that text.

(Granted, the document might warrant a less flippant tone, but I hope it suffices to convince you that it does indeed fit in this document.)

This could go into literally any other related document as well, but this one is most suitable because for the time being, this is the only document that does something with it, even if it's just illustrative examples. If it turns out that our solutions document also covers part of the TLS case, there is nothing to stop us from moving the comment as the document is advanced, and asking the experts to update the reference.

comments.author: chrysn
comments.body: If we'd manage to publish the -00 ahead of the cut-off (say, tomorrow?), it's well possible that we can already do a -01 with "has been added to".

comments.author: miri64
comments.body:
> If we'd manage to publish the -00 ahead of the cut-off (say, tomorrow?), it's well possible that we can already do a -01 with "has been added to".

What do you say @waehlisch, @tcschmidt? We can also iterate to -01 until monday which would include your feedback.

Everytime I read this, I stumble over it... this usually means something is not right ;-). Also, I think it helps finding the entry bye also naming the registry above the sub-registry. How about

```suggestion
The following entry was added to the “TLS Application-Layer Protocol Negotiation (ALPN) Protocol IDs” sub-registry of the ”Transport Layer Security (TLS) Extensions“ in consultation with the TLS registration review team:
```

"was added" will only be correct in the next revision; "is requested" is the usual terminology for while a document will request something at publication, and it's changed once IANA has done it (shortly before publication) to "has been requested" -- so in this situation "team was asked" sounds right to me. It's also not a sub-registry (cf. [faq](https://www.iana.org/help/protocol-registration)).

The rest of the changes I'm working into an update; may not even need the review team mention in there because that is implied by how the registration works, and more importantly not helpful to the reader.

pulls.title: IANA has processed the ALPN
pulls.author: chrysn
pulls.body: They have actually not yet; this will stay a draft PR until TLS experts have confirmed and IANA has acted.

pulls.title: Return to OSCORE problem statement only
pulls.author: miri64
pulls.body:
This

- Removes the parts that specify the discovery of CoAP transport protocols (will be specified in https://github.com/core-wg/transport-indication),
- Removes the parts that specify the discovery of CoAP over DTLS endpoinds (now specified in https://github.com/anr-bmbf-pivot/draft-lenders-core-coap-dtls-svcb), and
- Removes solution sketches and rather set objectives to solve problem space, making this document again more of a problem statement

comments.author: chrysn
comments.body: /me wonders where to best park the removed parts that do *not* yet have a better home.

comments.author: miri64
comments.body:
> /me wonders where to best park the removed parts that do _not_ yet have a better home.

There is always both the git and the draft history :-).

pulls.title: Fill section on SVCB URI conversion
pulls.author: chrysn
pulls.body:
This is way more verbose than I hoped.

One reason it is this verbose is that it aims to be a set of rules not only usable for DNR style cases (where we get a SVCB record for some non-CoAP service) but also for HTTPS style cases (where host and authority come from a URI, and we're not building the URI to connect to, but just a transport); the next iteration of transport-indication can build on this and provide a use case from there.

comments.author: chrysn
comments.body: Sorry, pushed to the wrong remote.
